utterances: And so we developed a prayer strategy, and we had people pray from Laredo to Duluth, Minnesota, and pray for 35 days.

In Laredo, San Antonio, Austin, Dallas, Oklahoma City, Kansas City, Des Moines, Minneapolis, and Duluth - to name a few cities.
Will travelers think it's strange when they see a cluster of people — heads bowed and hands uplifted — on a grassy strip next to the highway?
Steve Hill, the 54-year-old senior pastor at Heartland World Ministries, in the Dallas suburb of Irving is not concerned.
What would you rather have?
A group of young people praying on I-35 or a group of young people dealing drugs on I-35?

Though Light the Highway is not widely known, there is considerable skepticism within the steepled sanctuary of the Perkins School of Theology at Southern Methodist University in Dallas where William Lawrence is the dean.

America is full of religious groups that are testing the boundaries of what is possible to believe — much of which will have a very ephemeral lifespan and will fade from the scene because it's without substance.
On the whole, Lawrence looks askance at impersonal prayers for passing motorists.

Tossing out words to God as if I want to pray for the guy in the semi with a Louisiana license plate on it is not anything close to the encounter where somebody engages in what I know has been practiced in many places - truck stop ministries.

Yet roadside supplication is not all they do, Heartland World Ministries - the church at the center of Light of Highway - sends prayer teams into jails, malls, well-to-do neighborhoods and Dallas' gay bar district.
Joe Oden is the church's evangelism pastor.
We don't believe that God is going to come down and touch the asphalt.
But we believe that God is going to touch the people from the corridor of Laredo to Minneapolis, Minnesota.
And we're right off of I-35 here, and so this is an area where people are.
And we believe with Light the Highway that everyone needs Jesus — Caucasian people, black people, heterosexuals, homosexuals.
Especially gay people, every Friday night, a prayer team comes down here to Cedar Springs to conduct what they call a purity siege — hoping to set off a sort-of mass repentance.
While they're sometimes heckled, on this night interactions with club patrons are civil.
A 22-year-old evangelist from Little Rock named Kevin Wilks has challenged a 49-year-old gay Dallas interior designer named Kyle Perkins to reconsider his lifestyle.
Because just to be honest, you know, this is darkness out here.
No, it's not.

Writ large, this is more than a dialogue between a street preacher and a gay interior designer; it's a snatch of the same debate that's tearing apart Protestant denominations along every interstate in America.

While the church group seeks to light the highway with the redeemed souls of sinners, some people along congested Interstate 35 might request a different sort of supernatural intervention: How about fewer traffic jams?
